info.title: Deep Security Smart Check
info.description: Deep Security Smart Check is a container image scanner from Trend Micro.

token.name: Authorization
token.description:
Deep Security Smart Check uses token-based authentication for API requests. See `Sessions` for APIs related to token management, then include the token in an `Authorization` header with the `Bearer` scheme: 
Authorization: Bearer {token}

tags.name: Web hooks
tags.description: Outgoing web hooks from the scanner

user.description: The user to create a session for.

saml.description: The SAML response to create a session for.

selectedRole.description: If multiple role claims are present in the SAML response, set `selectedRole` to the role value that you want to assume for this session. Required if multiple role claims are present in the SAML response.

id.description: The session's unique system identifier.

href.description: The URL at which the session can be found.

token.description: The session token. Use the session token the `Authorization` header of subsequent requests: ```Authorization: Bearer SAMPLEeyJhbGciOiJSUz...```

created.description: The time that the session was created.

updated.description: The time that the session was last modified.

expires.description: The time that the session will expire.

roleSessionName.description: The session name provided for this session. SAML identity providers can set this by including a `RoleSessionName` claim in the SAML response.

id.description: The SAML identity provider's unique system identifier.

href.description: The URL at which the SAML identity provider can be found.

name.description: A name for the SAML identity provider.

description.example: My identity provider. Contact me@example.com for support.
description.description: (optional, default: `null`) A description for the SAML identity provider.

metadataURL.description: (optional, default: `null`) The URL for the identity provider metadata. If only the hostname is provided, the system will fill in the `https://[hostname]/FederationMetadata/2007-06/FederationMetadata.xml` template. Only one of `metadataURL` and `metadataXML` should be present.

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, Deep Security Smart Check will not verify TLS connections to the identity provider URL when retrieving the identity provider metadata. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between Deep Security Smart Check and the identity provider are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, Deep Security Smart Check will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs when retrieving the identity provider metadata. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, Deep Security Smart Check will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

metadataXML.description: (optional, default: `null`) If present, Deep Security Smart Check will use the provided metadata XML for the identity provider. Only one of `metadataURL` and `metadataXML` should be present.

id.description: The SAML identity provider's unique system identifier.

href.description: The URL at which the SAML identity provider can be found.

name.description: A name for the SAML identity provider.

description.example: My identity provider. Contact me@example.com for support.
description.description: (optional, default: `null`) A description for the SAML identity provider.

metadataURL.description: (optional, default: `null`) The URL for the identity provider metadata. If only the hostname is provided, the system will fill in the `https://[hostname]/FederationMetadata/2007-06/FederationMetadata.xml` template. Only one of `metadataURL` and `metadataXML` should be present.  If the `metadataURL` is present, Deep Security Smart Check will periodically retrieve the identity provider metadata.

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, Deep Security Smart Check will not verify TLS connections to the identity provider URL when retrieving the identity provider metadata. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between Deep Security Smart Check and the identity provider are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, Deep Security Smart Check will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs when retrieving the identity provider metadata. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, Deep Security Smart Check will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

validUntil.description: The time that the identity provider's certificate will expire.

status.description: Overall status of the identity provider. If the status is `failed`, the `detail` attribute will have more information.

detail.description: Reports additional detail when the status is `failed`.

created.description: The time that the identity provider was created.

updated.description: The time that the identity provider was last modified. If the `metadataURL` is present, Deep Security Smart Check will periodically retrieve the identity provider metadata.

message.example: Something went wrong. To fix it, try ...
message.description: The error message will explain what went wrong and will attempt to give some hints as to how to fix it.

fields.description: If present, the `fields` object will indicate which input fields had errors; the attribute name will be the name of the input field and the value will be an error message.

additionalProperties.description: An error message describing the error in the field identified by the property name.

name.description: (optional) A descriptive name for the web hook.

hookUrl.description: The URL that Deep Security Smart Check should `POST` the event payload to.

secret.description:
(optional) If you provide a `secret` value, then events sent over HTTP will include an `X-Scan-Event-Signature` header that is the SHA-256 HMAC of the event body using your secret as the key.

*This value is write-only: the API will not return the secret or show that it has been set.*

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, the web hook will not verify TLS connections to the web hook URL. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between the Deep Security Smart Check scanner and the hook URL are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, the web hook will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs for HTTPS web hook requests. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, the web hook will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

active.description: (optional, default: `false`). If `true`, the web hook will be invoked whenever a matching event occurs.

events.description: (optional, default: `["*"]`) If present, this is a list of event types that will be checked before calling the web hook. If the event type matches one of the elements of the list, the web hook will be called. If the list is empty, *all* events will match.

id.description: The unique ID assigned to this web hook.

href.description: The URL at which the web hook can be found.

name.description: (optional) A descriptive name for the web hook.

hookUrl.description: The URL that Deep Security Smart Check should `POST` the event payload to.

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, the web hook will not verify TLS connections to the web hook URL. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between the Deep Security Smart Check scanner and the hook URL are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, the web hook will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs for HTTPS web hook requests. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, the web hook will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

active.description: (optional, default: `false`). If `true`, the web hook will be invoked whenever a matching event occurs.

events.description: (optional, default: `["*"]`) If present, this is a list of event types that will be checked before calling the web hook. If the event type matches one of the elements of the list, the web hook will be called. If the list is empty, *all* events will match.

created.description: The time that the web hook was created.

updated.description: The time that the web hook was last updated.

name.description: (optional) A descriptive name for the scan.

source.description: The source of the image to scan.

type.description: The type of image that is being scanned.

registry.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The registry hostname or IP address.

repository.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The repository name.

tag.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The tag of the image to scan.

digest.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The digest value of the image to scan.

token.description: (optional) Use this if your source requires requests to be authorized using a bearer token. Requests will include an `Authorization: Bearer {token}` header.

username.description: (optional) Use this if your source requires requests to be authorized using basic username + password authentication. Requests will include an `Authorization: Basic {encoded username + password}` header.

password.description: (optional) Use this if your source requires requests to be authorized using basic username + password authentication. Requests will include an `Authorization: Basic {encoded username + password}` header.

aws.description: The AWS-specific information for authenticating to the registry.

region.description: The AWS region identifier for the region where the registry is located.

accessKeyID.description: The optional AWS IAM access key identifier to use when requesting the registry authorization token. If `roleID` is also set, then `accessKeyID` is the AWS IAM access key ID used to authorize the AWS STS `AssumeRole` request to assume the role. If `accessKeyID` is not set, then the default credential chain is used.

secretAccessKey.description: The optional AWS IAM secret access key to use when requesting the registry authorization token. If `roleID` is also set, then `secretAccessKey` is the AWS IAM secret access key used to authorize the AWS STS `AssumeRole` request to assume the role.

role.description: The optional AWS IAM role to assume when requesting the registry authorization token. If `accessKeyID` is also set, then `accessKeyID` and `secretAccessKey` are used to authorize the STS `AssumeRole` API request when assuming this role. If AccessKeyID is not set, then the default credential chain is used when assuming the role.

externalID.description: The optional "external ID" to use when calling the AWS STS `AssumeRole` API to assume the role specified in `roleID`. The external ID may be required by the trust policy on the role being assumed.

roleSessionName.description: The optional "role session name" to use when calling the AWS STS AssumeRole API to assume the role specified in `roleID`. If `roleSessionName` is not provided, then `DeepSecuritySmartCheck` will be used.

registry.description: The optional registry ID to use to get the registry authorization token. This can be used to access the registry in another AWS account. If not provided, the default registry will be used.

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, the scan will not verify TLS connections to the source URL. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between the Deep Security Smart Check scanner and the source are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, the scan will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs for HTTPS source requests. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, source requests will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

webhooks.description: (optional) A list of web hooks to call when events happen for the scan.

name.description: (optional) A descriptive name for the web hook.

hookUrl.description: The URL that Deep Security Smart Check should `POST` the event payload to.

secret.description:
(optional) If you provide a `secret` value, then events sent over HTTP will include an `X-Scan-Event-Signature` header that is the SHA-256 HMAC of the event body using your secret as the key.

*This value is write-only: the API will not return the secret or show that it has been set.*

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, the web hook will not verify TLS connections to the web hook URL. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between the Deep Security Smart Check scanner and the hook URL are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, the web hook will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs for HTTPS web hook requests. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, the web hook will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

active.description: (optional, default: `false`). If `true`, the web hook will be invoked whenever a matching event occurs.

events.description: (optional, default: `["*"]`) If present, this is a list of event types that will be checked before calling the web hook. If the event type matches one of the elements of the list, the web hook will be called. If the list is empty, *all* events will match.

detail.example: More details about the scan status
detail.description: (optional) More details about the scan status.

requested.description: The time that the scan was requested.

started.description: The time that the scan started. This value will not be present if the scan has not yet started.

updated.description: The time that the scan was last updated. This value will not be present if the scan has not yet started.

completed.description: The time that the scan completed. This value will not be present if the scan has not yet completed.

digest.description: The image digest for the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

os.description: The target operating system for the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

architecture.description: The target architecture for the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

labels.description: The labels associated with the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

results.description: A list of the scan results by layer.

id.description: A layer identifier. For scans of type `docker`, this will be the layer's `digest` value. This attribute will not be present for scans of type `http`.

createdAt.description: For scans of Docker images, this attribute will show the time at which the layer was created.

createdBy.description: For scans of Docker images, this attribute will show the Docker daemon command that ran to create this layer. This is not an exact match to the `Dockerfile` line, but will help to provide better context of the results.

malware.description: If present, a URL pointing to the list of malware that was found. See List layer malware findings.

vulnerabilities.description: If present, a URL pointing to the list of vulnerabilities that were found. See List layer vulnerability findings.

contents.description: If present, a URL pointing to the list of content scan results that were found. See List layer content findings.

scanners.description: Metadata about the scanners that produced the results.

malware.description: Metadata for the malware scanner.

updated.description: The time that the malware pattern database was last updated.

vulnerabilities.description: Metadata for the vulnerability scanner.

updated.description: The time that the vulnerabilities database was last updated.

vulnerabilityPatterns.description: Metadata for the vulnerability pattern scanner.

status.description: Availability of the vulnerability pattern scanner.

date.description: The time that the vulnerability patterns were last published.

updated.description: The time that the vulnerability patterns were last synchronized from the vulnerability feed.

malware.description:
The number of malware items that were found.
high:

contents.description: The number of content findings found by severity.

unknown.description: The number of content findings with unknown severity that were found.

unresolved.description: The number of unresolved content findings that were found by severity. Unresolved content findings are content findings that were found in the image and were not resolved by an override.

defcon1.description: The number of "Defcon1" vulnerabilities that were found.

high.description: The number of high-severity vulnerabilities that were found.

medium.description: The number of medium-severity vulnerabilities that were found.

low.description: The number of low-severity vulnerabilities that were found.

negligible.description: The number of negligible vulnerabilities that were found.

unknown.description: The number of vulnerabilities with unknown severity that were found.

unresolved.description: The number of unresolved vulnerabilities that were found by severity. Unresolved vulnerabilities are vulnerabilities that were found in a layer and were not fixed by an update in a subsequent layer.

critical.description: The number of critical vulnerabilities that were found.

high.description: The number of high-severity vulnerabilities that were found.

medium.description: The number of medium-severity vulnerabilities that were found.

low.description: The number of low-severity vulnerabilities that were found.

negligible.description: The number of negligible vulnerabilities that were found.

unknown.description: The number of vulnerabilities with unknown severity that were found.

requested.description: The time that the scan was requested.

completed.description: The time that the scan completed. This value will not be present if the scan has not yet completed.

digest.description: The image digest for the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

os.description: The target operating system for the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

architecture.description: The target architecture for the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

labels.description: The labels associated with the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

results.description: A list of the scan results by layer.

id.description: A layer identifier. For scans of type `docker`, this will be the layer's `digest` value. This attribute will not be present for scans of type `http`.

createdAt.description: For scans of Docker images, this attribute will show the time at which the layer was created.

createdBy.description: For scans of Docker images, this attribute will show the Docker daemon command that ran to create this layer. This is not an exact match to the `Dockerfile` line, but will help to provide better context of the results.

name.description: The name of the vulnerability.

namespaceName.description: The namespace that the package `name` is unique within.

severity.description:
The severity assigned to the vulnerability:
* `defcon1`: is a `critical` problem which has been manually highlighted by the team. It requires immediate attention.
* `critical`: a world-burning problem, exploitable for nearly all people in a default installation of Linux. Includes remote root privilege escalations, or massive data loss.
* `high`: a real problem, exploitable for many people in a default installation. Includes serious remote denial of services, local root privilege escalations, or data loss.
* `medium`: a real security problem, and is exploitable for many people. Includes network daemon denial of service attacks, cross-site scripting, and gaining user privileges. Updates should be made soon for this priority of issue.
* `low`: a security problem, but is hard to exploit due to environment, requires a user-assisted attack, a small install base, or does very little damage. These tend to be included in security updates only when higher-priority issues require an upgrade, or if many low-priority issues have built up.
* `negligible`: is technically a security problem, but is only theoretical in nature, requires a very special situation, has almost no install base, or does no real damage. These tend not to get backported from upstreams, and will likely not be included in security updates unless there is an easy fix and some other issue causes an update.

name.description: (optional) A descriptive name for the scan.

source.description: The source of the image to scan.

repository.description: The repository name.

tag.description: The tag of the image to scan.

digest.description: The digest value of the image to scan.

webhooks.description: (optional) A list of web hooks to call when events happen for the scan.

name.description: (optional) A descriptive name for the web hook.

hookUrl.description: The URL that Deep Security Smart Check should `POST` the event payload to.

secret.description:
(optional) If you provide a `secret` value, then events sent over HTTP will include an `X-Scan-Event-Signature` header that is the SHA-256 HMAC of the event body using your secret as the key.

*This value is write-only: the API will not return the secret or show that it has been set.*

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, the web hook will not verify TLS connections to the web hook URL. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between the Deep Security Smart Check scanner and the hook URL are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, the web hook will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs for HTTPS web hook requests. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, the web hook will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

active.description: (optional, default: `false`). If `true`, the web hook will be invoked whenever a matching event occurs.

events.description: (optional, default: `["*"]`) If present, this is a list of event types that will be checked before calling the web hook. If the event type matches one of the elements of the list, the web hook will be called. If the list is empty, *all* events will match.

name.description: The name to display for the registry. If not specified, the registry `host` value will be used as the initial name.

description.description: A longer-form note to attach to the registry.
description.example: This registry is an example, and this description is similarly exemplary.

host.description: The host where the registry can be found. Required except when using Amazon Elastic Container Registry.

credentials.description: Credentials to use when accessing the registry.

username.description: (optional) Use this if your source requires requests to be authorized using basic username + password authentication. Requests will include an `Authorization: Basic {encoded username + password}` header.

password.description: (optional) Use this if your source requires requests to be authorized using basic username + password authentication. Requests will include an `Authorization: Basic {encoded username + password}` header.

aws.description: The AWS-specific information for authenticating to the registry.

region.description: The AWS region identifier for the region where the registry is located.

accessKeyID.description: The optional AWS IAM access key identifier to use when requesting the registry authorization token. If `roleID` is also set, then `accessKeyID` is the AWS IAM access key ID used to authorize the AWS STS `AssumeRole` request to assume the role. If `accessKeyID` is not set, then the default credential chain is used.

secretAccessKey.description: The optional AWS IAM secret access key to use when requesting the registry authorization token. If `roleID` is also set, then `secretAccessKey` is the AWS IAM secret access key used to authorize the AWS STS `AssumeRole` request to assume the role.

role.description: The optional AWS IAM role to assume when requesting the registry authorization token. If `accessKeyID` is also set, then `accessKeyID` and `secretAccessKey` are used to authorize the STS `AssumeRole` API request when assuming this role. If AccessKeyID is not set, then the default credential chain is used when assuming the role.

externalID.description: The optional "external ID" to use when calling the AWS STS `AssumeRole` API to assume the role specified in `roleID`. The external ID may be required by the trust policy on the role being assumed.

roleSessionName.description: The optional "role session name" to use when calling the AWS STS AssumeRole API to assume the role specified in `roleID`. If `roleSessionName` is not provided, then `DeepSecuritySmartCheck` will be used.

registry.description: The optional registry ID to use to get the registry authorization token. This can be used to access the registry in another AWS account. If not provided, the default registry will be used.

insecureSkipVerify.description: If `true`, Deep Security Smart Check will not verify TLS connections to the registry. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between the Deep Security Smart Check scanner and the registry are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, the service will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs for registry requests. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, the service will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

filter.description: The filters that define the repositories and tags that will be synchronized from the registry. The maximum size of the filters for a registry is 32768 bytes.

include.description: A pattern to use when determining which images to synchronize (include) from the registry.

exclude.description: A pattern to use when determining which images to synchronize (exclude) from the registry.

schedule.description: If `true`, this registry will be scheduled for daily re-scan.

If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

status.description:
Reports the status of the connection from Deep Security Smart Check to the registry.
* `pending`: Deep Security Smart Check has not yet attempted to connect to the registry
* `ok`: The last connection attempt to the registry was successful.
* `failed`: The last connection attempt to the registry failed.

statusDetail.description: Reports additional detail when the status is `failed`.

registries.description: The number of registries that are currently permitted by the license. A value of `-1` indicates that unlimited licenses can be created.

updates.description: If the system is unlicensed, it will not receive malware pattern updates and the value for `updates` will be `false`.

cursor.name: cursor

dryrunCreate.name: dryrun
dryrunCreate.description: Use the `dryrun=true` query parameter to indicate that the request should only be tested for validity and should not actually create a record. The response code will indicate whether the request was OK (`200 OK`) or whether there was a problem in the request.

dryrunUpdate.name: dryrun
dryrunUpdate.description: Use the `dryrun=true` query parameter to indicate that the request should only be tested for validity and should not actually modify the record. The response code will indicate whether the request was OK (`200 OK`) or whether there was a problem in the request.

dryrunDelete.name: dryrun
dryrunDelete.description: Use the `dryrun=true` query parameter to indicate that the request should only be tested for validity and should not actually delete the record. The response code will indicate whether the request was OK (`200 OK`) or whether there was a problem in the request.

parameters.name: expand
parameters.description: A comma-separated list of attributes to expand in the results.

parameters.description: An encoded value used to retrieve the next set of results for a query that returns more than `limit` results.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of records to return.

parameters.name: query
parameters.description: Space-separated strings to search for.

parameters.name: X-Api-Version
parameters.description: The version of the API to use.

get.description: Retrieve a list of SAML identity providers.

200.description: The response body contains the SAML identity providers.

Link.description: If more data exists, a `Link` header with the `next` relation type will be present as a pointer to the next page of data. Example: ```Link: </api/roles?cursor=dGhpcyB2YWx1ZSBpcyBvcGFxdWUsIGRlY29kaW5nIGl0IHdvbid0IGJlIHVzZWZ1bAo>; rel="next"```

Sunset.description: If present, this API endpoint has been deprecated and may be removed at any point after the reported date. The timestamp is an HTTP date string in the format `Fri, 11 Nov 2018 11:11:11 GMT`.

X-Request-Id.description: The request ID assigned to this request.

X-Api-Version.description: The API version used in this request.

X-Api-Notice.description: If present, this header will include important API information. We will use this header as one way to notify you that a new API version is available or that the API version you are using is going to be removed.

providers.description: The list of SAML identity providers.

id.description: The SAML identity provider's unique system identifier.

href.description: The URL at which the SAML identity provider can be found.

name.description: A name for the SAML identity provider.

description.example: My identity provider. Contact me@example.com for support.
description.description: (optional, default: `null`) A description for the SAML identity provider.

metadataURL.description: (optional, default: `null`) The URL for the identity provider metadata. If only the hostname is provided, the system will fill in the `https://[hostname]/FederationMetadata/2007-06/FederationMetadata.xml` template. Only one of `metadataURL` and `metadataXML` should be present.  If the `metadataURL` is present, Deep Security Smart Check will periodically retrieve the identity provider metadata.

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, Deep Security Smart Check will not verify TLS connections to the identity provider URL when retrieving the identity provider metadata. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between Deep Security Smart Check and the identity provider are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, Deep Security Smart Check will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs when retrieving the identity provider metadata. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, Deep Security Smart Check will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

validUntil.description: The time that the identity provider's certificate will expire.

status.description: Overall status of the identity provider. If the status is `failed`, the `detail` attribute will have more information.

detail.description: Reports additional detail when the status is `failed`.

created.description: The time that the identity provider was created.

updated.description: The time that the identity provider was last modified. If the `metadataURL` is present, Deep Security Smart Check will periodically retrieve the identity provider metadata.

next.description: An encoded value that you can use to retrieve the next set of results for a query. If `next` is not present, then there are no more results available.

name.description: A name for the SAML identity provider.

metadataURL.description: (optional, default: `null`) The URL for the identity provider metadata. If only the hostname is provided, the system will fill in the `https://[hostname]/FederationMetadata/2007-06/FederationMetadata.xml` template. Only one of `metadataURL` and `metadataXML` should be present.

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, Deep Security Smart Check will not verify TLS connections to the identity provider URL when retrieving the identity provider metadata. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between Deep Security Smart Check and the identity provider are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, Deep Security Smart Check will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs when retrieving the identity provider metadata. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, Deep Security Smart Check will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

metadataXML.description: (optional, default: `null`) If present, Deep Security Smart Check will use the provided metadata XML for the identity provider. Only one of `metadataURL` and `metadataXML` should be present.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The system-assigned identity provider ID.

get.description: Retrieve details for a SAML identity provider.

parameters.name: expand
parameters.description: A comma-separated list of attributes to expand in the results.

parameters.name: X-Api-Version
parameters.description: The version of the API to use.

200.description: The response body contains the identity provider details.

Sunset.description: If present, this API endpoint has been deprecated and may be removed at any point after the reported date. The timestamp is an HTTP date string in the format `Fri, 11 Nov 2018 11:11:11 GMT`.

X-Request-Id.description: The request ID assigned to this request.

X-Api-Version.description: The API version used in this request.

X-Api-Notice.description: If present, this header will include important API information. We will use this header as one way to notify you that a new API version is available or that the API you are using is going to be removed.

id.description: The SAML identity provider's unique system identifier.

href.description: The URL at which the SAML identity provider can be found.

name.description: A name for the SAML identity provider.

description.example: My identity provider. Contact me@example.com for support.
description.description: (optional, default: `null`) A description for the SAML identity provider.

metadataURL.description: (optional, default: `null`) The URL for the identity provider metadata. If only the hostname is provided, the system will fill in the `https://[hostname]/FederationMetadata/2007-06/FederationMetadata.xml` template. Only one of `metadataURL` and `metadataXML` should be present.  If the `metadataURL` is present, Deep Security Smart Check will periodically retrieve the identity provider metadata.

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, Deep Security Smart Check will not verify TLS connections to the identity provider URL when retrieving the identity provider metadata. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between Deep Security Smart Check and the identity provider are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, Deep Security Smart Check will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs when retrieving the identity provider metadata. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, Deep Security Smart Check will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

validUntil.description: The time that the identity provider's certificate will expire.

status.description: Overall status of the identity provider. If the status is `failed`, the `detail` attribute will have more information.

detail.description: Reports additional detail when the status is `failed`.

created.description: The time that the identity provider was created.

updated.description: The time that the identity provider was last modified. If the `metadataURL` is present, Deep Security Smart Check will periodically retrieve the identity provider metadata.

id.description: The role's unique system identifier.

href.description: The URL at which the role can be found.

name.description: A name for the role.

description.example: An administrator has full access to all operations.

policies.description: A list of policies for the role. The total size of the policy list must be less than 32768 bytes.

version.description: The policy format version.

statements.description: The list of statements in the policy.

effect.description: The policy effect if the statement matches.

actions.description: A list of actions. Actions take the form `resourceType:operation` and can have a wildcard in either the `resourceType` or `operation` part. You can also use `*` to match all actions. The required action is listed with each API operation.

created.description: The time that the role was created.

updated.description: The time that the role was last modified.

next.description: An encoded value that you can use to retrieve the next set of results for a query. If `next` is not present, then there are no more results available.

It's possible that trying again will help, but it's more likely that you're out of luck for the moment.

Sunset.description: If present, this API endpoint has been deprecated and may be removed at any point after the reported date. The timestamp is an HTTP date string in the format `Fri, 11 Nov 2018 11:11:11 GMT`.

X-Api-Notice.description: If present, this header will include important API information. We will use this header as one way to notify you that a new API version is available or that the API you are using is going to be removed.

Link.description: If this API endpoint has been deprecated, a `Link` header with the `sunset` relation type may be present with a link to human-readable article describing the API change.

post.description: Create a session. This can be used to create either a simple user session with a userid and password or to assume a role using SAML.

user.description: The user to create a session for.

saml.description: The SAML response to create a session for.

selectedRole.description: If multiple role claims are present in the SAML response, set `selectedRole` to the role value that you want to assume for this session. Required if multiple role claims are present in the SAML response.

parameters.name: dryrun
parameters.description: Use the `dryrun=true` query parameter to indicate that the request should only be tested for validity and should not actually create a record. The response code will indicate whether the request was OK (`200 OK`) or whether there was a problem in the request.

parameters.name: X-Api-Version
parameters.description: The version of the API to use.

200.description: The response body contains the session details. This response will only be returned if the `dryrun=true` query parameter was sent.

get.description: Retrieve a list of scans. Scans are returned in descending order of creation time, so the latest scan is returned first.

parameters.name: expand
parameters.description: A comma-separated list of attributes to expand in the results.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: An encoded value used to retrieve the next set of results for a query that returns more than `limit` results.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of records to return.

parameters.name: registry
parameters.description: When present, the `registry` query parameter will filter the list of scans to those scans where the `source.registry` contains the provided value. If the `exact` query parameter is also provided (and `true`), the filter will do an exact match on the value.

parameters.name: repository
parameters.description: When present, the `repository` query parameter will filter the list of scans to those scans where the `source.repository` contains the provided value. If the `exact` query parameter is also provided (and `true`), the filter will do an exact match on the value.

parameters.name: tag
parameters.description: When present, the `tag` query parameter will filter the list of scans to those scans where the `source.tag` contains the provided value. If the `exact` query parameter is also provided (and `true`), the filter will do an exact match on the value.

parameters.name: digest
parameters.description: When present, the `digest` query parameter will filter the list of scans to those scans where the image digest exactly matches the provided value.

parameters.name: exact
parameters.description: When present (and true), any filtering done using the `registry`, `repository`, and `tag` query parameters will be done using exact matches.

parameters.name: status
parameters.description: When present, the `status` query parameter will filter the list of scans to those scans where the `status` value contains one of the provided values. Valid values in the list are `pending`, `in-progress`, `completed-with-findings`, `completed-no-findings`, `failed`, `cancelled`. Invalid values are ignored.

parameters.name: X-Api-Version
parameters.description: The version of the API to use.

200.description: The response body contains the scan objects.

Sunset.description: If present, this API endpoint has been deprecated and may be removed at any point after the reported date. The timestamp is an HTTP date string in the format `Fri, 11 Nov 2018 11:11:11 GMT`.

X-Request-Id.description: The request ID assigned to this request.

X-Api-Version.description: The API version used in this request.

X-Api-Notice.description: If present, this header will include important API information. We will use this header as one way to notify you that a new API version is available or that the API you are using is going to be removed.

scans.description: A list of results for the query.

id.description: The unique ID assigned to this scan.

href.description: The URL to the scan resource.

name.description: If you provided a name for the scan, it will be returned here.

type.description: The type of image that is being scanned.

registry.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The registry hostname or IP address.

repository.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The repository name.

tag.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The tag of the image to scan.

digest.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The digest value of the image to scan.

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, the scan will not verify TLS connections to the source URL. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between the Deep Security Smart Check scanner and the source are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, the scan will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs for HTTPS web hook requests. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, source requests will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

detail.example: More details about the scan status
detail.description: (optional) More details about the scan status.

requested.description: The time that the scan was requested.

started.description: The time that the scan started. This value will not be present if the scan has not yet started.

updated.description: The time that the scan was last updated. This value will not be present if the scan has not yet started.

completed.description: The time that the scan completed. This value will not be present if the scan has not yet completed.

digest.description: The image digest for the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

os.description: The target operating system for the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

architecture.description: The target architecture for the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

labels.description: The labels associated with the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

results.description: A list of the scan results by layer.

id.description: A layer identifier. For scans of type `docker`, this will be the layer's `digest` value. This attribute will not be present for scans of type `http`.

createdAt.description: For scans of Docker images, this attribute will show the time at which the layer was created.

createdBy.description: For scans of Docker images, this attribute will show the Docker daemon command that ran to create this layer. This is not an exact match to the `Dockerfile` line, but will help to provide better context of the results.

malware.description: If present, a URL pointing to the list of malware that was found. See List layer malware findings.

vulnerabilities.description: If present, a URL pointing to the list of vulnerabilities that were found. See List layer vulnerability findings.

contents.description: If present, a URL pointing to the list of content scan results that were found. See List layer content findings.

scanners.description: Metadata about the scanners that produced the results.

malware.description: Metadata for the malware scanner.

updated.description: The time that the malware pattern database was last updated.

vulnerabilities.description: Metadata for the vulnerability scanner.

updated.description: The time that the vulnerabilities database was last updated.

vulnerabilityPatterns.description: Metadata for the vulnerability pattern scanner.

status.description: Availability of the vulnerability pattern scanner.

date.description: The time that the vulnerability patterns were last published.

updated.description: The time that the vulnerability patterns were last synchronized from the vulnerability feed.

name.description: (optional) A descriptive name for the scan.

source.description: The source of the image to scan.

type.description: The type of image that is being scanned.

registry.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The registry hostname or IP address.

repository.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The repository name.

tag.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The tag of the image to scan.

digest.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The digest value of the image to scan.

token.description: (optional) Use this if your source requires requests to be authorized using a bearer token. Requests will include an `Authorization: Bearer {token}` header.

username.description: (optional) Use this if your source requires requests to be authorized using basic username + password authentication. Requests will include an `Authorization: Basic {encoded username + password}` header.

password.description: (optional) Use this if your source requires requests to be authorized using basic username + password authentication. Requests will include an `Authorization: Basic {encoded username + password}` header.

aws.description: The AWS-specific information for authenticating to the registry.

region.description: The AWS region identifier for the region where the registry is located.

accessKeyID.description: The optional AWS IAM access key identifier to use when requesting the registry authorization token. If `roleID` is also set, then `accessKeyID` is the AWS IAM access key ID used to authorize the AWS STS `AssumeRole` request to assume the role. If `accessKeyID` is not set, then the default credential chain is used.

secretAccessKey.description: The optional AWS IAM secret access key to use when requesting the registry authorization token. If `roleID` is also set, then `secretAccessKey` is the AWS IAM secret access key used to authorize the AWS STS `AssumeRole` request to assume the role.

role.description: The optional AWS IAM role to assume when requesting the registry authorization token. If `accessKeyID` is also set, then `accessKeyID` and `secretAccessKey` are used to authorize the STS `AssumeRole` API request when assuming this role. If AccessKeyID is not set, then the default credential chain is used when assuming the role.

externalID.description: The optional "external ID" to use when calling the AWS STS `AssumeRole` API to assume the role specified in `roleID`. The external ID may be required by the trust policy on the role being assumed.

roleSessionName.description: The optional "role session name" to use when calling the AWS STS AssumeRole API to assume the role specified in `roleID`. If `roleSessionName` is not provided, then `DeepSecuritySmartCheck` will be used.

registry.description: The optional registry ID to use to get the registry authorization token. This can be used to access the registry in another AWS account. If not provided, the default registry will be used.

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, the scan will not verify TLS connections to the source URL. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between the Deep Security Smart Check scanner and the source are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, the scan will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs for HTTPS source requests. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, source requests will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

webhooks.description: (optional) A list of web hooks to call when events happen for the scan.

name.description: (optional) A descriptive name for the web hook.

hookUrl.description: The URL that Deep Security Smart Check should `POST` the event payload to.

secret.description:
(optional) If you provide a `secret` value, then events sent over HTTP will include an `X-Scan-Event-Signature` header that is the SHA-256 HMAC of the event body using your secret as the key.

*This value is write-only: the API will not return the secret or show that it has been set.*

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, the web hook will not verify TLS connections to the web hook URL. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between the Deep Security Smart Check scanner and the hook URL are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, the web hook will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs for HTTPS web hook requests. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, the web hook will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

active.description: (optional, default: `false`). If `true`, the web hook will be invoked whenever a matching event occurs.

events.description: (optional, default: `["*"]`) If present, this is a list of event types that will be checked before calling the web hook. If the event type matches one of the elements of the list, the web hook will be called. If the list is empty, *all* events will match.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The scan ID.

parameters.name: expand
parameters.description: The properties of each scan that should be expanded in the response. The default (`all`) causes all properties to be expanded.

parameters.name: X-Api-Version
parameters.description: The version of the API to use.

200.description: The response body contains the scan object.

Sunset.description: If present, this API endpoint has been deprecated and may be removed at any point after the reported date. The timestamp is an HTTP date string in the format `Fri, 11 Nov 2018 11:11:11 GMT`.

X-Request-Id.description: The request ID assigned to this request.

X-Api-Version.description: The API version used in this request.

X-Api-Notice.description: If present, this header will include important API information. We will use this header as one way to notify you that a new API version is available or that the API you are using is going to be removed.

id.description: The unique ID assigned to this scan.

href.description: The URL to the scan resource.

name.description: If you provided a name for the scan, it will be returned here.

type.description: The type of image that is being scanned.

registry.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The registry hostname or IP address.

repository.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The repository name.

tag.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The tag of the image to scan.

digest.description: (for scan type `docker` only) The digest value of the image to scan.

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, the scan will not verify TLS connections to the source URL. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between the Deep Security Smart Check scanner and the source are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, the scan will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs for HTTPS web hook requests. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, source requests will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

detail.example: More details about the scan status
detail.description: (optional) More details about the scan status.

requested.description: The time that the scan was requested.

started.description: The time that the scan started. This value will not be present if the scan has not yet started.

updated.description: The time that the scan was last updated. This value will not be present if the scan has not yet started.

completed.description: The time that the scan completed. This value will not be present if the scan has not yet completed.

digest.description: The image digest for the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

os.description: The target operating system for the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

architecture.description: The target architecture for the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

labels.description: The labels associated with the scanned image. This value will only be present for Docker scans.

results.description: A list of the scan results by layer.

id.description: A layer identifier. For scans of type `docker`, this will be the layer's `digest` value. This attribute will not be present for scans of type `http`.

createdAt.description: For scans of Docker images, this attribute will show the time at which the layer was created.

createdBy.description: For scans of Docker images, this attribute will show the Docker daemon command that ran to create this layer. This is not an exact match to the `Dockerfile` line, but will help to provide better context of the results.

malware.description: If present, a URL pointing to the list of malware that was found. See List layer malware findings.

vulnerabilities.description: If present, a URL pointing to the list of vulnerabilities that were found. See List layer vulnerability findings.

contents.description: If present, a URL pointing to the list of content scan results that were found. See List layer content findings.

scanners.description: Metadata about the scanners that produced the results.

malware.description: Metadata for the malware scanner.

updated.description: The time that the malware pattern database was last updated.

vulnerabilities.description: Metadata for the vulnerability scanner.

updated.description: The time that the vulnerabilities database was last updated.

vulnerabilityPatterns.description: Metadata for the vulnerability pattern scanner.

status.description: Availability of the vulnerability pattern scanner.

date.description: The time that the vulnerability patterns were last published.

updated.description: The time that the vulnerability patterns were last synchronized from the vulnerability feed.

malware.description:
The number of malware items that were found.
high:

contents.description: The number of content findings found by severity.

total.description: The total number of content findings categorized by severity.

defcon1.description: The number of "Defcon1" content findings that were found.

critical.description: The number of critical content findings that were found.

high.description: The number of high-severity content findings that were found.

medium.description: The number of medium-severity content findings that were found.

low.description: The number of low-severity content findings that were found.

negligible.description: The number of negligible content findings that were found.

unknown.description: The number of content findings with unknown severity that were found.

unresolved.description: The number of unresolved content findings that were found by severity. Unresolved content findings are content findings that were found in the image and were not resolved by an override.

vulnerabilities.description: A list of results for the query.

name.description: The name of an installed package with known vulnerabilities.

namespaceName.description: The namespace that the package `name` is unique within.

version.description: The package version that was detected.

vulnerabilities.description: A list of the known vulnerabilities in this package.

description.description: A description of the known vulnerability in this package.

fixedBy.description: The version of the package where the vulnerability has been resolved.

fixed.description: If present, this object will describe the fix and what layer the fix is present in.

name.description: The name of the package.

namespaceName.description: The namespace that the package `name` is unique within.

version.description: The package version that was detected.

layer.description: The layer identifier where the fixed package version was detected.

id.description: The unique ID assigned to this override.

href.description: The URL to the override.

name.description: The name of the vulnerability being overridden.

package.description: The package where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all packages.

version.description: The package version where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all package versions.

registry.description: The image registry where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all registries.

repository.description: The image repository where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all repositories. Use `organization/*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all repositories under `organization`.

tag.description: The image tag where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all image tags.

created.description: The time that the override was created.

updated.description: The time that the override was last updated.

expires.description: The time that the override expires. If not present, the override will not expire.

comment.description: A free-form comment field for your notes.
comment.example: Allowing CVE-2019-00000 for 30 days. Contact alice@example.com for details.

link.description: A link to more information about the vulnerability.

name.description: The name of the vulnerability.

namespaceName.description: The namespace that the package `name` is unique within.

severity.description:
The severity assigned to the vulnerability:
* `defcon1`: is a `critical` problem which has been manually highlighted by the team. It requires immediate attention.
* `critical`: a world-burning problem, exploitable for nearly all people in a default installation of Linux. Includes remote root privilege escalations, or massive data loss.
* `high`: a real problem, exploitable for many people in a default installation. Includes serious remote denial of services, local root privilege escalations, or data loss.
* `medium`: a real security problem, and is exploitable for many people. Includes network daemon denial of service attacks, cross-site scripting, and gaining user privileges. Updates should be made soon for this priority of issue.
* `low`: a security problem, but is hard to exploit due to environment, requires a user-assisted attack, a small install base, or does very little damage. These tend to be included in security updates only when higher-priority issues require an upgrade, or if many low-priority issues have built up.
* `negligible`: is technically a security problem, but is only theoretical in nature, requires a very special situation, has almost no install base, or does no real damage. These tend not to get backported from upstreams, and will likely not be included in security updates unless there is an easy fix and some other issue causes an update.

findings.description: Metrics for the vulnerabilities that were found.

defcon1.description: The number of "Defcon1" vulnerabilities that were found.

critical.description: The number of critical vulnerabilities that were found.

high.description: The number of high-severity vulnerabilities that were found.

medium.description: The number of medium-severity vulnerabilities that were found.

low.description: The number of low-severity vulnerabilities that were found.

negligible.description: The number of negligible vulnerabilities that were found.

unknown.description: The number of vulnerabilities with unknown severity that were found.

next.description: An encoded value that you can use to retrieve the next set of results for a query. If `next` is not present, then there are no more results available.

contents.description: A list of results for the query.

filename.description: The file where the issue was detected by the content scanner.

rule.description: The content rule name that matches the file content.

ruleset.description: The URL to the ruleset resource.

description.example: This is a rule.
description.description: The description of the content rule.

severity.description: The severity assigned to the content finding.

metadata.description: The metadata of the content rule.

tags.description: The tags of the content rule.

id.description: The unique ID assigned to this override.

href.description: The URL to the override.

filename.description: The filename for the finding being overridden.

rule.description: The rule that is being is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for all rules.

registry.description: The image registry where the finding is overridden. Use `*` to override findings in all registries.

repository.description: The image repository where the finding is overridden. Use `*` to override findings in all repositories. Use `organization/*` to override findings in all repositories under `organization`.

tag.description: The image tag where the finding is overridden. Use `*` to override findings in all image tags.

created.description: The time that the override was created.

updated.description: The time that the override was last updated.

expires.description: The time that the override expires. If not present, the override will not expire.

comment.description: A free-form comment field for your notes.
comment.example: Allowing demo.pem private key for 30 days. Contact alice@example.com for details.

next.description: An encoded value that you can use to retrieve the next set of results for a query. If `next` is not present, then there are no more results available.

profile.description: The profile for the identifier that is being overridden. Use `*` to override findings for all profiles.

registry.description: The image registry where the finding is overridden. Use `*` to override findings in all registries.

repository.description: The image repository where the finding is overridden. Use `*` to override findings in all repositories. Use `organization/*` to override findings in all repositories under `organization`.

tag.description: The image tag where the finding is overridden. Use `*` to override findings in all image tags.

created.description: The time that the override was created.

updated.description: The time that the override was last updated.

expires.description: The time that the override expires. If not present, the override will not expire.

comment.description: A free-form comment field for your notes.
comment.example: Allowing CCE-26876-3 for 30 days. Contact alice@example.com for details.

next.description: An encoded value that you can use to retrieve the next set of results for a query. If `next` is not present, then there are no more results available.

webhooks.description: A list of results for the query.

id.description: The unique ID assigned to this web hook.

href.description: The URL at which the web hook can be found.

name.description: (optional) A descriptive name for the web hook.

hookUrl.description: The URL that Deep Security Smart Check should `POST` the event payload to.

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, the web hook will not verify TLS connections to the web hook URL. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between the Deep Security Smart Check scanner and the hook URL are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, the web hook will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs for HTTPS web hook requests. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, the web hook will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

active.description: (optional, default: `false`). If `true`, the web hook will be invoked whenever a matching event occurs.

events.description: (optional, default: `["*"]`) If present, this is a list of event types that will be checked before calling the web hook. If the event type matches one of the elements of the list, the web hook will be called. If the list is empty, *all* events will match.

created.description: The time that the web hook was created.

updated.description: The time that the web hook was last updated.

next.description: An encoded value that you can use to retrieve the next set of results for a query. If `next` is not present, then there are no more results available.

name.description: (optional) A descriptive name for the web hook.

hookUrl.description: The URL that Deep Security Smart Check should `POST` the event payload to.

secret.description:
(optional) If you provide a `secret` value, then events sent over HTTP will include an `X-Scan-Event-Signature` header that is the SHA-256 HMAC of the event body using your secret as the key.

*This value is write-only: the API will not return the secret or show that it has been set.*

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, the web hook will not verify TLS connections to the web hook URL. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between the Deep Security Smart Check scanner and the hook URL are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, the web hook will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs for HTTPS web hook requests. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, the web hook will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

active.description: (optional, default: `false`). If `true`, the web hook will be invoked whenever a matching event occurs.

events.description: (optional, default: `["*"]`) If present, this is a list of event types that will be checked before calling the web hook. If the event type matches one of the elements of the list, the web hook will be called. If the list is empty, *all* events will match.

insecureSkipVerify.description: (optional, default: `false`) If `true`, the web hook will not verify TLS connections to the web hook URL. Use this only in controlled environments where you know that connections between the Deep Security Smart Check scanner and the hook URL are secured by other means.

rootCAs.description:
(optional, default: `null`) If present, the web hook will use the provided root CAs as the trusted root CAs for HTTPS web hook requests. The value should be a base-64 encoded list of PEM-encoded certificates. If not present, the web hook will use a set of built-in trusted root CAs.
If `insecureSkipVerify` is set to `true`, then the root CAs are not checked.

active.description: (optional, default: `false`). If `true`, the web hook will be invoked whenever a matching event occurs.

events.description: (optional, default: `["*"]`) If present, this is a list of event types that will be checked before calling the web hook. If the event type matches one of the elements of the list, the web hook will be called. If the list is empty, *all* events will match.

created.description: The time that the web hook was created.

updated.description: The time that the web hook was last updated.

*This value is write-only: the API will not return the secret or show that it has been set.*

get.description: Get the list of content ruleset collections.

parameters.name: expand
parameters.description: A comma-separated list of attributes to expand in the results.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: An encoded value used to retrieve the next set of results for a query that returns more than `limit` results.

parameters.name: query
parameters.description: Space-separated strings to search for.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of records to return.

parameters.description: The version of the API to use.

200.description: The response body contains the list of ruleset collection objects.

post.description: Add a content ruleset collection to manage rules. Default rules will be automatically inserted into the ruleset created.

name.description: The name of this ruleset collection.

default.description: The global ruleset collection used for content scan. There can only be one default ruleset collection at all time. If this value is true, the value of other collection will be reset to false.

name.description: The name of this ruleset.

disabled.description: If set to true, this ruleset will not be used for scan.

rulesets.description: The rulesets belonging to this collection.

parameters.name: dryrun
parameters.description: Use the `dryrun=true` query parameter to indicate that the request should only be tested for validity and should not actually create a record. The response code will indicate whether the request was OK (`200 OK`) or whether there was a problem in the request.

parameters.name: X-Api-Version
parameters.description: The version of the API to use.

200.description: The response body contains the ruleset collection details. This response will only be returned if the `dryrun=true` query parameter was sent.

post.description: Modify a content ruleset collection. Rulesets cannot be modifed with this API.

name.description: The name of this ruleset collection.

default.description: The global ruleset collection used for content scan. There can only be one default ruleset collection at all time. If this value is true, the value of other collection will be reset to false.

It's possible that trying again will help, but it's more likely that you're out of luck for the moment.

post.description: Update a content ruleset. Built-in rulesets are not allowed to be modified except disabling/enabling.

name.description: The name of this ruleset.

disabled.description: If set to true, this ruleset will not be used for scan.

name.description: The name of this ruleset.

href.description: The URL to the ruleset resource.

ruleset.description: Base64-encoded yara ruleset. In some special rulesets, it will not be displayed.

disabled.description: If set to true, this ruleset will not be used for scan.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: An encoded value used to retrieve the next set of results for a query that returns more than `limit` results.

parameters.name: query
parameters.description: Space-separated strings to search for.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of records to return.

parameters.name: X-Api-Version
parameters.description: The version of the API to use.

200.description: The response body contains the list of vulnerability finding override objects.

Sunset.description: If present, this API endpoint has been deprecated and may be removed at any point after the reported date. The timestamp is an HTTP date string in the format `Fri, 11 Nov 2018 11:11:11 GMT`.

X-Request-Id.description: The request ID assigned to this request.

X-Api-Version.description: The API version used in this request.

X-Api-Notice.description: If present, this header will include important API information. We will use this header as one way to notify you that a new API version is available or that the API you are using is going to be removed.

overrides.description: A list of results for the query.

id.description: The unique ID assigned to this override.

href.description: The URL to the override.

name.description: The name of the vulnerability being overridden.

package.description: The package where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all packages.

version.description: The package version where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all package versions.

registry.description: The image registry where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all registries.

repository.description: The image repository where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all repositories. Use `organization/*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all repositories under `organization`.

tag.description: The image tag where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all image tags.

created.description: The time that the override was created.

updated.description: The time that the override was last updated.

expires.description: The time that the override expires. If not present, the override will not expire.

comment.description: A free-form comment field for your notes.
comment.example: Allowing CVE-2019-00000 for 30 days. Contact alice@example.com for details.

next.description: An encoded value that you can use to retrieve the next set of results for a query. If `next` is not present, then there are no more results available.

X-Api-Notice.description: If present, this header will include important API information. We will use this header as one way to notify you that a new API version is available or that the API you are using is going to be removed.

Retry-After.description: The amount of time (in seconds) you should wait before trying this request again.

Link.description: If this API endpoint has been deprecated, a `Link` header with the `sunset` relation type may be present with a link to human-readable article describing the API change.

message.example: Something went wrong. To fix it, try ...
message.description: The error message will explain what went wrong and will attempt to give some hints as to how to fix it.

fields.description: If present, the `fields` object will indicate which input fields had errors; the attribute name will be the name of the input field and the value will be an error message.

additionalProperties.description: An error message describing the error in the field identified by the property name.

name.description: The name of the vulnerability being overridden.

package.description: The package where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all packages.

version.description: The package version where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all package versions.

registry.description: The image registry where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all registries.

repository.description: The image repository where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all repositories. Use `organization/*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all repositories under `organization`.

tag.description: The image tag where the vulnerability is overridden. Use `*` to override findings for this vulnerability in all image tags.

expires.description: The time that the override expires. If not present, the override will not expire.

comment.description: A free-form comment field for your notes.
comment.example: Allowing CVE-2019-00000 for 30 days. Contact alice@example.com for details.

parameters.name: dryrun
parameters.description: Use the `dryrun=true` query parameter to indicate that the request should only be tested for validity and should not actually create a record. The response code will indicate whether the request was OK (`200 OK`) or whether there was a problem in the request.

parameters.name: X-Api-Version
parameters.description: The version of the API to use.

200.description: The response body contains the override details. This response will only be returned if the `dryrun=true` query parameter was sent.
